div.head: The Author to the Reader, concerning the Topographicall Glasse.

lg.l: COme you, whose eyes stand not in enuious head,
Whose tongue with Criticke humors is not fed,
And in this Glasse, vnto your comfort view,
Such needfull workes that much may profit you.
The grounds of Art haue brought it forth for thee,
Which we haue suckt from famous Geometrie,
With Theorm's mixt and demonstrations rare,
Such as in hiddan Propositions are:
Heer's no vaine shew: illusions haue no place,
No spirit confind, no hatefull painted face,
No eye-deceiuing glasse, no Cristall braue,
Which from the frozen seas we often haue.
But in a faire and most perspicuous light,
The earthy Globe lies subiect to thy sight.
Whose Center's deepe, whose continent is great,
Here mixt with cold, and there with burning heat:
As Phoebus beames do sparkling from him glide,
Or as in torrid Zones we do abide.
This frame enough for all the world to view,
This Glasse layes in a small proportion true.
That like an Eagle towring vp aloft,
Whole regions thou mayst view and reuiew oft.
Discoursing now of Europe in particular,
And then of other Countries distant farre.
Now of Ierusalem that was before,
And then of Rome, by Tybers siluer shore.
See here mount Sion and mount Moria then,
That on their backes bare old Ierusalem:
Though now mount Caluarie hath got the grace,
Which erst was but an execution place.
Learne here to bound the Alpes, Spaine, France and all,
That yeelds those vines whence iuycie grapes do fall.
America, the new found land beside,
And eke those Southerne parts yet vndiscride.
See how to measure plot, and part out lands;
As drest in Floras sommer robes it stands.
Or as it's rent vp with the tering plowe,
O • hid with f • eezing ice or melting snowe:
See here the height of hils, or see their ods,
That Gyants meant to dart against the gods.
See here the Sunne, whose beames do Comets fire,
That all the world with terror may admire.
Behold the Moone, and fixed Starres so bright,
That guide the Pilots in the darkest night.
Looke how the Planets with the whirling Sphere,
To our Horizon fierie meteots beare.
Gilding the blacke brow of the vgly night,
With burning Dragons and such fearefull light.
Looke on them all: see in this little Glasse,
Their heigth so tooke as ne'r in English was.
Wouldst plant a Towne, or situate a house,
Or force the water take a wished course.
Wouldst seeke the heigth or distance of a Towne,
Or vndermine a Fort to blow it downe▪
Or what wouldst do belonging to this Art,
But in this Glasse thou mayst behold apart?
Then vse him well, my word I pawne, he's true,
Let small defects be but supplide by you.
Of which few scapt my Pen, no store the Presse,
Where either be, in kindnesse vse redresse.
So shall my Pen not be imployd in vaine,
To please thee more when I do write againe.
